section.hand:
Copie of my letter to yo
r
L. July 15 1592.

page.lettertext:
fol.98r
May it please your good L. The 10
th
of this moneth
being come as farre as
Swoll,
in going toward
the campe, and there
attending the arrival of
e
councell of State
, I receaved those l
re
s
and scedules, w
ch
her
Ma
tie
and my
LL.
and yo
r
L. sent unto mee
bearing date
e first and second of this p
nt
. When
e Councell
was come thether, w
ch
was the next daie after, having commoned
first w
th
S
r
Francis Vere
, I procured an assembly not onely
of
e councel, but of
e Deputies of
e Provinces, and I
offered them to open her Ma
t
l
re
s to
e
States,
in case they
found them selves thertoo to be sufficiently authorised. W
ch
I did
for good respect, for that it had bin a question in their dealing
before
whether they in that place, or those at the Hage, having both like
commission from the generality of
e contrey, were to excercise the
powre of
e general States. But in this matter of her Ma
ty
they disclaimed that authority, and put mee over to the Hage for
delivery of my letters. Howbeit I omitted not to signifie the
effect of those letters, and in all
t
I was able, to amplifie the
reasons, and to pray them not to hinder the execution of my
their
charge. For her Hig
nes
promise was so past, that it could
not be revoked, and I had order therafter, to cause the troupes
that were desired, to put them selves in p
nt
redines. They were
much amazed at
e matter, and used great intreatie, that no
separation might be made of
e English from the rest, till the
campe were come to
Coevoerden:
upon hope that
e ennemy
upon the view of their numbers, would come to p
nt
composition.
But conferring upon it w
th
S
r
Francis Vere, and
ceaving plainely
by discours, that it was but a motion to gaine a litel time, for
that
e ennemy is hardy and
e place well provided, and finding
therw
th
al that their marching first to Coevoerden, and then afterward
to
Flusshing
might both weaken them in strength, and put them
farre out of order, when her Hig
nes
would be served, I persisted
precisely upon the pointes of my charge, and requested them
earnestly to graunt a patent to every companie to repaire to his
garrison, and that there they might remaine, untill such time as
they were sent for. This I urged continually, as having
no kinde of liberty, to dispose in other sorte of her Ma
t
desseing:
fol.98v
w
ch
was also so confirmed by S
r
Francis Vere unto them: who
continueth there in place, and hath resolved not to alter, but to
prosecute
e matter as I have begunne it. In
e meane time
because they did refuse to determin theruppon, referring mee
hither to this assembly of
e States, I departed from thence the
next daie following, and came hether to
e Hage w
th
all possible
speed. I left
e campe at
t
time within a mile of
Swoll,
from whence I thinke they will not stirre, till they heare
what is said by the States of this place. Yesterday morning
I presented my letters in their publick meeting, w
ch
when I had
heard, bring openly read (for I had no coppie sent unto mee)
I noted a certaine clause, w
ch
, I am very much afraide, wil put
mee to some trouble. For it goeth w
th
condition that if
the armie of
e States may bee commodiously dissolved, and the
forces of her Ma
ty
w
ch
have served in the army conveniently returned,
that then the
french King
shall have
e use of those succors that are
promised unto him. But, as if I had not understood it
I urged very earnestly
e King
necessity, and
e importance of
the matter in respect of these contreys, and proposed all
e point
of
e instructions sent unto mee, w
th
out leaving to their choice, to
denie her Hig
nes
her demaund. They saied but litel as then to
any parte of my speech, but as their custome is commonly in
causes of consequence, they required some time to signifie their
answere. They had notice of the matter before my coming to
the
Hage,
and receaved out of
England
a coppie of
e Contract
between her Hig
nes
and
e King: w
ch
I
ceave by some frind
they do highlie dislike to have bin donne w
th
out their privitie, in
regard of that Contract w
ch
is made w
th
them alredy. But
if they seeme in that respect to complaine in publick place, I
have matter enough for answere. I ame onely now to seeke
w
ch
waie I shalbee able to reconcile the forsesaid clause, w
th
that
w
ch
I proposed, for as I learne under hand by a frinde among
the States, they do minde to take hold of those woordes of
e letter,
and will seeme to take no knowledge, that her Ma
ty
ment oth
r
wise
but to make her suite conditional. I will excuse it as I
fol.99r
may upon the writers oversighte, and keepe
e course that is begonne
in preparing
e companies, and in declaring plainely to them, that
both
e contract w
th
e King, and her Ma
ties
lett
r
to my self doth
apparantly signifie that there must bee no deniall. Nevertheles
if they chaunce to bee so wilfull, as to stand in contestation, and
to oppose against mee, as they may, it wilbee greatly behoofefull
that I bee strengthened from her Hig
nes
, w
th
some plainer knowledge
of her meaning. and becaus it is a matter of so great a
consyderation, I thought w
th
all speed to advertise you of yt
and humbly to beseeche you, to write about it w
th
e sooneste.
I have certaine intelligence from
e Campe at this very instant
that S
r
Francis Vere hath obtained patent
for his troupes, to
bee placed in Townes adjoyning to
Swoll,
&
t
e rest of the
campe ys marched toward
Coevoerden. I am also told
assuredly
t
the answere of
e States is redy to be sent,
and ys framed upon the avantage of
e point aforementioned.
Count Phillip
w
th
his troupes
t
have served in
France
is expected every houre: and as soone as they returne
M
r
Buzenval
hath in charge, to request
e loane of so much
monie, as may suffice for certaine monethes, to intertaine
2000 men, to be levied in such sorte as
e King shall
appoint. And for mine owne part I beleave, hee shall speede
of his purpose. For if they in this contrey shalbe forced to
surcease from an offensive warre, as mee think
there ys
apparance, when
e Englishe are departed, there wilbee somuch
remaining of this sommers contribution, as the King may bee
pleasure d , and an overplus reserved.
And thus I take
my humble leave. From
e
Hage.
15 July 1592.
